Many of the detracting factors are the people both playing and managing the game, not the game itself. The main PVP attraction of the game WoE (War of Empurium) is dominated by hypocritical guilds who proclaim on the official RO forums to be strictly against cheating while there is video documentation of their members cheating. Many of whom avoid bans simply by being friends with the GMs and CMs (Game Masters and Comunity Managers).These cheats include things like NDL (No delay, allows you to spam skills faster then you should ever be able to normally), auto pot (automatically spams potions in your inventroy faster then any human could do whenever you recieve damage to instantly heal any damage received), Maya Purple hack (within the game there are cards that drop from monsters that one can use to enchant items and one of the is a somewhat rare card called maya purple that lets you see invisible players) the list goes on.The GMs themselves have also assisted in the theft of high end items from various guild leaders by other guild leaders, screwed over large portions of the player base and economy to cater to single high profile players desires and even assisted in the creation of various cheating programs.Unlike most other ragnarok servers iRo has a feature that removes all incentive to explore the world called gramps. An NPC who resides within the eden group who gives you a daily quest to hunt 400 of two different monsters and gives you (if I'm not mistaken) 1.5x the combined exp of the 400 monsters as quest exp and sends you to a special map where these monster are. The monsters change each week and what they change to is somewhat dependant on what the community wants (or what one high profile player wants). usually the quest is very straight forward, other times it throws monsters that the general populace is untrained to handle as most of the time the monsters are usually ones that can be one shot by the primary AoE damage dealer Rangers, and there are a decent number of monsters that will end up in these maps that can not be one shot by a ranger and can easily wipe untrained parties.To say gearing in the game is reliant on the cash shop would be a profound understatement. Most of the important gear either comes from the cash shop, needs to be upgraded with items from the cash shop to be worthwile or both. Many items require being upgraded to +7 or +9 to see any useful bonuses, but the safe limit for most gears is +4 and failing an upgrade past that limit destroys that item permanently. However in the cash shop there is usually a box that may or may not give you safe 7 certs, which allow you to safely "attempt" to upgrade past the safe upgrade level once per certificate (these certificates can be obtained in game but only through the exchange of high end boss drops or lengthy quests). To upgrade past +7 you must either buy special ores from the cash shop that will cause your gear to downgrade if you fail an upgrade or wait for an event to be put in that has increased rates of upgrading your gear past +7 but can also downgrade your gear using a seperate cash shop ore.In closing if you really want to try this game, I strongly recommend you either find a private server that suits you or find a way to play on one of the other countries servers.TL;DR: playerbase consists of stupid entitled brats, GMs encourage them to be stupid entitled brats, ALL the big guilds cheat, almost all of your leveling through 56 to 175 can be done without ever stepping foot outside of any town (can even do 1-175 without stepping foot oustide of a town if you have connections) and cash shop items are mandatory to achieve anything. Go find a good private server of this game, you probably won't regret it.

Of that, I suspect 150-200 are vending and about 100 are actual human players. The rest are botting.With the population so low, it does make the game a bit more fun, in terms of not having to fight over mob spawns (unless it is a profitable area with decent returns, in which case you'll be fighting with botters for mobs) and Prontera is, pretty much, the only place one will find Vendors. 												Can't help but recommend this game. Yes it's old like other people have said but it's graphics were setup in  way so they don't age. Wonderfull 2D sprites in a amazing easy on the eyes 3D world. I've actual played this game since late Alpha, early Beta, about the 1999-2000 time frame. And I still play to this day, though mainly on the classic server.Beside the easy on the eye graphics another amazing feature is the customization you can do with your character's stats and skills. Unlike nearly every other game on the market you stats matter. Your character's ablity will change massively based on what stats you take.Want a Swordsman that dodges attacks and hits faster instead of just taking hits and having high hit points ? Put points in to Agility instead of Vitality. This means you trade High Hitpoints and high defense for High Flee (dodge) and high Attack speed. You then could go on to make a Agility based knight or Crusader with your swordsman. Or go the middle of the ground and do a hybrid of Agility and Vitality, You might not dodge as well as pure agility or have as much hitpoints as pure Vitality but you can take less damage per hits then agility based characters, and dodge more then pure vitality. And this is just the start of it, You can go pure support acolyte forgoing increased melee damage for the ability to heal massive amounts of damage, or for a true acolyte and have a mix of Melee damage and Healing ability. Want a Mage that beats things as well as toss magic at them? Put points into Strength, Vitality, and Agility, instead of going pure intelligence. You lose magic damage but can dodge, take hits, and do better melee damage then a pure magic caster. Go the sage route and get the skills that let you move while casting and add the chance to auto cast a low level bolt spell while your hitting monsters.  Like making money, while beating on things with axes, swords or maces? Go a Merchant class character. They don't have the Melee skills of other classes but you can carry more loot or healing potions items then any other class, can buy cheaper and sell for more then any other classes, have access to a cart to carry even more loot/potions, and use your fortune to pay the god of the merchants to attack your enemies (Mammonite skill). Want to craft potions or weapons, take your Merchant to ether Alchemist or Blacksmith. And even Blacksmith and Alchemist have the ability to go Pure Battle, pure Crafting, or a Middle ground, not building items as well as their pure counter parts but still being able to fight for themselves.And there are many other classes to chose from like Archers, thief, TaeKwon Kid, Ninja, Gunslinger ans Super Novice. On top of all that it's free to play, with subscription players (only 7 bucks a month) only get 50% more experience and loot drops, larger storage and other minor abilities. I've spent most of my time since it's gone free to play not using a subscription (they call it VIP) and had no problems with it. So give it a try, nothing to lose but a lot of your free time, and a lot of fun to be had.edit: fixed some spelling issues

												I've played RO since 2000, but only discovered that it was in steam a few months ago. The steam version itself is ok... Not the best definately not, but not the worst either. It is a pixel-ish game. So if graphics are a big thing for you, RO is not for you. RO is possibly one of my favorite RPGs of all time. Not just from nostalgia alone, but there are certain decisions Gravity made that was just amazing. Here are some of them:-You don't have to chose your class immediately.  -- it's a small design factor since you do go to a class system, but having the player wait till lvl 10 to get a class makes all     that grinding a bit better. You grind in every RPG, but knowing that that grind can really change your character progression in a more significant way than just a few skills and attributes for your already established class. -Player to player trade is encouraged with the merchant class  -- This is a big factor to me since it gives all that dead space worth something. Most MMORPGs have this grand city, with only 30-40% actually relevant. Having a AH does make trading simpler, but less exciting in my opinion. Since selling your stuff to another player is best with the merchant class, most guilds have at least one, and most players have at least one character that is a merchant, and you kinda do it with a stall in the city street, and since you dont want to be an a$$ the city streets have more purpose than simple pathways. RO is beyond its peak. I can say that out loud, but theres no doubt it is a great MMORPG. I wish  there are more games like RO.

												Overall: 6.5/10Art: 8/10Design: 5/10Graphics: 4/10Sound: 9/10With more than 10 years of history, Ragnarok Online is an old MMORPG game to many. At a quick glance - it may seem fun to you but however, the community of this game really makes up a lot of your in-game experience. Talking about community, this game has real players who gave you the cold shoulders because of the vast amount of bots in the game. Lot's of Philipino and Asian players, you know you could reach out to them and make some friends if you are one of them - and assuming they don't ignore you. They are generally cocky and arrogant, but few handful would still help you out if you are lucky enough to meet them. Noobs start out weak (of course) and without a proper guild, party and friends, its almost impossible to get powerful unless you spend on the game. Well, duh. That's the main purpose.This game has a rich art base and many fans would draw them for fun, laughter, peace and joy. It's a 3D game, and a very successful one during its time - one would not simply ignore the art and just play the game. The art is great in my point of view and I do admit that their art makes me get hooked to the game. You will rave about the awesome sprite of your character, no matter the class you are in.The core design of the game offers you guild wars, Player VS Player, vending, and turn-ins. (for exp) It's a wonderful world out there to explore as well, though you might just go for the shortcut and teleport around the world if you purchase their premium services. With that said, the design is very multiplayer heavy - and you will only gain from it if you play with someone else. There will be events held often in the game, be sure to take advantage of it and not miss it ! Wide diversity of classes, you will always find a class that suits you most. However, some special classes do not offer you rebirths - so you lack some extra stat and skill points which makes you weaker than most players.Graphics is cool. The skills animation are awesome in my opinion and they are truly worth raving about as you scale later on in to the game where you do job advancement for your character. There are items in the game that needs to be purchased in real cash to exchange for better graphical aesthetics. Other than that, the animation might be a little choppy due to the latency of the game - it depends on where you are from and all.Sound. The reason why I gave sound a 9/10 is because they are really awesome. You can grab them in your directory for free as well, and I have used the BGMs of this game before in my school projects as well. They have a wide range from classical to metal, and different maps invoke your feelings and really puts you into the world of Ragnarok with their music.Summary: Do NOT try to play this game alone, because you will probably ragequit due to all these bots who would KS you and helpdesk takes a super long time in looking and solving your queries. It can be a very fun game despite my critics, you should try this timeless game out before giving judgement of your own. Support the game if you like it, but I would highly doubt it because of poor customer service. Lastly, great way to kill time with your friends! I have hundreds of playing hours in this game and and made awesome lifelong friends - talking about a gamer for 4 good years in here.

												AWESOME Massive Online Multiplayer Role Playing GameRagnarok has been my third RPG game that I have probably ever played. The first two, League of Legends and Dofus, really weren't the greatest thing- hence role playing games aren't my selectable game genre. But Ragnarok is quite pleasurable for casual gamers.The game features the usual Role Playing tactic in which you build your character in your first few levels, then take a pernmament "job" that determines the type of player you play forever. Of course, some people might get bored of their class eventually, but Ragnarok makes up for this lack. Ragnarok allows you to have three character profiles at a time. So if you are willing to start fresh or try another character class, you can! No more having to stick to one destiny for the rest of E T E R N I T Y .Ragnarok can be confusing to new players, the game is open freely and vast, and easy to get lost in. you will spawn at first near the heart of the entire game map, from there you can build up your job skill, then be let go into the depths of Ragnarok's world. All areas have different mobs that can be passive or hostile, they also vary by Level everywhere. You can find a relaxing spot here and there with easy passive mobs, or you can run into a mob that is 40 levels HIGHER than you, and it WILL ATTACK you at it's will. This leaves gamers to be adventureous, alert, and competitive. This concept is what probably brings in my attention.Ragnarok is also fun to play with friends. Beacause it is Free to Play, you can ask your friend to join without any worries. The probable downside is you have to create an account on their website, which shouldn't be too hard if you have spare emails for probable spam.I highly recommend this game to great RPG players who are looking for challenge, Ragnarok, despite the other RPGs I have played, really adds up to have many differences that give players more freedom. Role Playing Gamers would not be disappointed.I somewhat recommend this game to those who casually play RPGs, Ragnarok Online is a great game to play on your spare time, but sometimes you can get really lost like me - if that happens.... pray that you'll make it back without dying, or just die and respawn at the heart of the map, you get to keep your stuff, but you loose some of your experience. 												Seems they allow you to play three different versions of Ragnarok I on Steam. Classic, RePlay, and their newest edition. I've been a constant fan ever since they first started; I still remember when they had issues properly coding the 'Bash' move for swordsmen. I started playing their newest server, and though it stays reminiscent of what I'm used to, it seems to have molded for the future that MMOs in general have carved out for themselves. Instead of monthly fees, they have a cash shop. They make items for new interesting events thta I wish I could take place in, for say, the hat quests, but even though I am a high enough level to collect the items, I am not a high enough level to initiate the holiday event. I find that fairly irritating, personally. Holiday events should be available to all, and accomplished by those whom can, but it shouldn't be limited to those that spend hours and hours, if not possibly days in front of their computer trying to speed level in order to catch the event in time.But, that's just an event. The market has certainly changed. I remember when a 4-leaf clover costed millions because of what you had to go through in order to afford it. You would have to painstakingly kill hundreds or thousands of vine whipping stationary, but pretty mean monsters, pretty much giving up the hours you normally would use to level in order to find that one item. Now, they're being sold on market for 50k. Advanced drop rate? Or is it because they're so easily accessible now as a chance item in Giftboxes?I have more virtues than vices for this game still. There are things that have changed, things that I wish was still what I am used to, but I can always play the 'classic' server. I still love the community, and it's pretty social! It's still worth hours of fun, and some time I want to see them have cool achievements for Steam for me to accomplish. I highly recomend this game as a simple MMO that has been striving with a several thousand person community for about ten years. It was my first MMO, and it will probably be my last, at that. Why? Because every time I step away from it, one month later I get another random craving for it and end up running right back to this amazing community.

There is no specific path to take in the game, you can go anywhere at any time assuming you can survive. The farther you get from a town, the stronger the enemies become, and it's not uncommon to get into dangerous or challenging situations facing a horde of enemies. The game is best played with friends or a guild IMO, but out of 10 years of online gaming, i haven't played an overall better MMO, especially from KR.

												I have been an avid iRO fan since 2004, and the game has seen its ups and downs. There has always been a pretty decent community and the Dev's are pretty good at keeping the game updated and working on issues - which is why the game has lasted so long and has a pretty positive player base. Since coming to Steam its definitely seen an increase in players, with even a new server added recently - so if youre a veteran player or new this is a great time to start! I'd like to mention also that there has almost always been an issue with botting, however they're taking an active role in supressing it and they keep at it regularly as well. All in all, a great MMO to play if you enjoy the Korean Anime styled type and you want to give a good piece of gaming history a try. There is more than enough to keep you interested with its huge arsenal of classes, builds, items, skills and gameplay. As a personal word of advice for in game longevity - no matter what class you choose to play, make a merchant and learn to sell items to help make some zenny. Anything from selling items to NPC's for even more, or selling valuable equipment and cards. You can check on Ragial.com for a good look at how things are selling too - money is a big factor in your ability to do end game so hopefully this well help some of you out!

												It's been forever since I've played RO or any of its private server counterparts. To be completely honest, I, taken by nostalgia, wanted to try out RO again solely because I wanted to relive the past. This may sound hypocritical because I'm trying to brag about how great this game is, but RO isn't very exciting compared to all of today's great games. It was the greatest thing in the world 10 years ago, but not the greatest anymore. However, it's not terrible and for veterans it brings a tear to one's eye to hear the old theme song of the capital city playing in the background. I tried out RO 2 first because I wanted to see what changes were made. To my disappointment some of the game mechanics in RO 2, which worked well for RO, didn't really transition well. So I thought "oh well" and moved onto to RO. It took a little grinding to get started, but I fairly enjoyed it. Some people might find grinding miserable, but after playing years of fast paced games it was suprisingly enjoyable to slow down a bit. The graphics are 2D/3D...and of course it's crap since it was made 10 years ago. (but it was some really great crap back then) The controls consist of the function keys, alt+(letter keys) and just clicking. Moving and attacking are clicking/clicking+holding. Hotkeys are function keys. Very simple~ but it worked fabulously. The training grounds gave me a bit of a refresher on all the little details and it's a good place to start out as a beginner if you don't know anything at all. This is great because RO can be a bit complicated even for veterans. There are a bunch of requirements you have to meet for certain things and stats you have build on for certain jobs. You might hate tutorials, but trust me... you'll need all the free items, easy levels, and explanations as possible or the beginner stages will be slow and painful. I can't critique on the rest of the game since I haven't gotten too much into it myself, but if memory serves me right this game was well worth my time. Once you make some friends or get into a guild the game will be a little easier to understand and you'll start to play strategically (or not...I prefer strategy). It's a lot more fun to play in parties (especially with experienced players that don't do all the work, but assist the little guys) vs clicking on a bunch of monsters...alone... for hours. Since your characters don't "dodge" (they stand still and exchange blows with the monster you're locked on) the most you can get out of solo playing is really just standing still and hitting monsters. The beauty of rpg's is to figure out (for example) who's going to tank, who's going to heal, who's going to range, etc. And seriously it's going to suck if you solo...A little tangent here- I loved how the game gave the option of playing the classic RO vs the updated one. When I played in the newer one I couldn't help feel like a total noob because maps were different and monsters had changed levels/locations. The classic RO option let me get used to the game and relive those younger days :DIf you're looking for high end graphics and fast paced gaming... this is not for you. If you're looking to get into an old mmorpg because you want a change of pace, go ahead. If you're a veteran of the game and you haven't played in a while just try it out for a bit. I'm not asking you to commit. It's really hard to start from square one, but playing it once in a while still feels great and you might be able to get serious about it later.

												I played this game a lot in college but over time it's lost it's appeal to me.  It's a beautiful game with lush environments and colorful sprites and monsters.  However, it gets repetitive and boring when you start leveling up in hours instead of minutes and the charm wears off.  For a purely casual RPG gamer side step this one.  This is also not a game you can play on your own which is bad for a solo player like me.  You will need friends or join a guild or you will never see all of the game's content.  To it's credit the combat is solid and the skill trees are good and leveling is satisfying.  I did though spend a lot of time trying to close out a dozen hot-key bars I accidentally opened.  All 100 different maps, charts, bars, screens have a macro to turn them on and off in your display and each one is explained briefly and only once in the 2+ hour tutorial section and good luck figuring out how to close them.   If you can spare the time to grind all the way to 100 twice, create another character to craft all your gear and potions, farm for card drops for weeks, and turn Ragnarok into essentially a full time job then go for it.  I am already tired of it and I'm not even level 30 so there's no way I have the patience for that.

Many hours were burned through with this game and having not played it in two years, I'm sure many more will be, this time on Steam. Even after the game went free to play, it maintened everything that made it great.
